Monkey kidney fibroblast COS-1 cells were maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum. In preparation for transfection, cells were grown in a 75-cm2 flask to 60–70% confluency, washed once with phosphate-buffered saline, and removed by trypsinization. Cells (40,000/well) were seeded in a 24-well tray and grown in 400 μl of DMEM supplemented with 5% fetal calf serum. After the cells were attached in the well (3–4 h), the medium was removed, and the cells were washed once with phosphate-buffered saline, and then the medium was replaced with serum-free RPMI medium. Cells were incubated for 2 h for synchronization prior to transfection. For each triplicate transfection, the CYP24 promoter luciferase construct (600 ng) was mixed with 15 μl of Hepes buffer (20 mm, pH 7.4) in an Eppendorf tube with 600 ng of Ets-1 expression clone (pEFBos-Ets-1, Ref. 18Dwivedi P.P. Omdahl J.L. Kola I. Hume D.A. May B.K. J. Biol. For most experiments, 600 ng of pRSV-hVDR was also transfected to compensate for the low endogenous VDR level. In all transfections, the final amount of DNA was kept constant by addition of the appropriate vector plasmid. In another tube, 7.5 μg of DOTAP was diluted to 15 μl in Hepes buffer and mixed with 15 μl of diluted DNA plasmids. After incubation for 10 min at room temperature for DNA·DOTAP complex formation, 10 μl of this DNA·DOTAP complex was aliquoted into three wells of a 24-well plate. The following day, the medium was replaced with 400 μl of serum-free RPMI medium, and cells were further cultured for 24 h in the presence of a specific kinase inhibitor and/or 1,25D or ethanol carrier prior to harvesting. Dual luciferase activity in cell lysates was determined by the DLR assay kit using a luminometer model TD 20/20 (Turner Design Instruments, Sunnyvale, CA). Human choriocarcinoma cells, JEG-3, were cultured for 24 h in DMEM containing 5% charcoal-stripped fetal calf serum. Cells were cotransfected with 200 ng of reporter plasmid (pG5E1b-Luc) and 50 ng of pRL-TK-Luc (transfection efficiency control) with 500 ng each of GAL4-Ets-1 or GAL4-Ets-1T38A plasmids with either VP16-TR or VP16-VDR expression plasmids using the DOTAP transfection protocol as described earlier in this section. After 24 h, medium was changed, and 1,25D was added as indicated. Cells were further cultured for 24 h in serum-free DMEM and then harvested for DLR assays. COS-1 cells with or without transfected HA-tagged expression constructs (confluent 10-cm dishes) were stimulated with 1,25D, H2O2, or phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate for the times indicated at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 in air. The incubations were terminated by removing the medium and washing the cells once with Hanks' buffered salts solution (4 °C). The cells were scraped and lysed in 200 μl of buffer A (25 mm Tris/HCl, pH 7.5, 2 mm EGTA, 25 mm NaCl, 1 mmNa3VO4, 38 mmp-nitrophenyl phosphate, 10 μg/ml each of pepstatin A, benzamidine, aprotinin, and leupeptin, 2 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and 1 mm dithiothreitol) by constant rotation for 2 h at 4 °C. Soluble fractions were collected after centrifugation (16,000 × g, 3 min, 4 °C), and the protein content of the lysates was determined by Lowry's method of protein determination. Samples were stored at −70 °C until assayed. For Western blot analysis, samples were mixed with Laemmli buffer and boiled before being stored. Lysates containing equal amounts of protein were precleared with protein A-Sepharose (15 μl) before being incubated with anti-HA antibody (3 μg of each) to immunoprecipitate HA-ERK2, HA-ERK5, HA-RXRα, or HA-Ets-1. The antigen-antibody complexes were sedimented by the addition of protein A-Sepharose (15 μl) and centrifugation (16,000 ×g for 20 s, 4 °C). The immune complexes were washed (2 × 200 ml) with buffer A. The immune complexes were washed with assay buffer (1 × 200 μl) (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.2, 20 mm glycerophosphate, 10 mm Sigma 104, 10 mm MgCl2, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 50 μm orthovanadate, 20 mm cold ATP), and kinase assays were started by the addition of assay buffer (30 ml) containing 10 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP and MBP, GST-RXR, GST-Ets-1, His-Ets-1, or GST-VDR (10–15 μg/sample). In some assays, GST-tagged mutants of RXR or Ets-1 were used. After 20 min at 30 °C, the assays were terminated by the addition of Laemmli buffer (15 ml), and the samples were boiled for 5 min. Phosphorylated substrates were fractionated on 16% (MBP) or 10% (GST-tagged proteins) SDS-PAGE gels and detected using an Instant Imager (Packard Instruments, Canberra, Australia). To determine the level of ERK1 and ERK2 dual phosphorylation, lysates containing equal amounts of denatured proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE (12% gels). After transfer to nitrocellulose, the blot was probed with anti-ACTIVETM ERK antibody. Immunoreactive bands were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (32Hii C.S.T. Huang Z.H. Bilney A.J. Costabile M. Murray A.W. Rathjen D.A. Der C.J. Ferrante A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19277-19282Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). The blot was stripped using a Western blot recycling kit (Alpha Diagnostic International, San Antonio, Texas) and reprobed with anti-ERK2 antibody to confirm equal protein loading between lanes. To detect co-immunoprecipitated proteins, immunoprecipitated samples were subjected to Western blot analysis, and the blots were probed first with one antibody, stripped, and reprobed with another antibody as indicated under “Results.” The plasmid pCYP24WT(−298)-Luc contains −298 bp of rat CYP24 promoter sequence encompassing the two known functional VDREs and the Ets-1 protein binding site designated EBS (Fig.1). We have previously shown that Ets-1 present in nuclear extracts of COS-1 cells binds EBS, whereas exogenous Ets-1 can stimulate 1,25D induction of a truncated CYP24promoter containing only the first VDRE and the nearby EBS (18Dwivedi P.P. Omdahl J.L. Kola I. Hume D.A. May B.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 47-55Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Initial studies were undertaken to evaluate the effect of ectopically expressed wild type Ets-1 on 1,25D induction of the −298 bpCYP24 promoter. With hormone alone, a 4.8-fold level of induction was observed, and overexpressed Ets-1 increased this to 11.2-fold (Fig.2A). Endogenous VDR is limiting in these cells, and exogenously expressed human VDR (hVDR) increased 1,25D induction to 26-fold, whereas a combination of exogenous VDR and Ets-1 further enhanced induction to 56-fold, the latter reflecting a functional cooperation of these transcription factors. When the EBS was inactivated (pCYP24mEBS(−298)-Luc), the level of induction by exogenous Ets-1 and VDR together was reduced to 14.0-fold (Fig. 2A). Ets-1 alone did not alter basal promoter activity in the absence of hormone (data not shown). A mutant form of the wild type Ets-1 protein was examined in which threonine residue 38 was mutated to alanine (Ets-1 T38A). This threonine residue is conserved in several Ets proteins, and based on other work (31Sun H. Charles C.H. Lau L.F. Tonks N.K. Cell. 1993; 75: 487-493Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1023) Google Scholar), it is likely to be phosphorylated in a Ras-dependent fashion, although the identity of any specific MAP kinase involved is not known (33Yang B.-S. Hauser C.A. Henkel G. Colman M.S. Beveren C.V. Stacy K.J. Hume D.A. Maki R.A. Ostrowski M.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 538-547Crossref PubMed Scopus (316) Google Scholar). The 26-fold level of induction observed with exogenous VDR (Fig. 2A) was lowered to 16-fold when the mutant Ets-1 T38A was overexpressed, a value comparable with that seen when the EBS was mutated (Fig.2A). This result shows that the expressed mutant Ets-1 protein competes strongly with endogenous Ets proteins for binding to EBS but is unable to functionally cooperate with VDR·RXR complexes on either VDRE-1 or VDRE-2 in response to 1,25D. In control experiments, it was established that Ets-1 T38A did not alter basal expression of the construct (results not shown), whereas mutagenesis of both VDREs abolished 1,25D induction (Fig. 2A). These data demonstrate that wild type Ets-1 substantially enhance vitamin D-induced promoter activity in the presence of two VDREs and that the threonine 38 residue of Ets-1 is vital for its functional cooperation with VDR in the presence of 1,25D. Experiments were undertaken to determine whether the functional cooperation observed between exogenously expressed hVDR and Ets-1 occurred on one or both VDREs present in the CYP24 promoter. As observed already, overexpression of hVDR alone gave a 26-fold level of induction with pCYP24WT(−298)-Luc, and this was increased to 56-fold with coexpression of Ets-1 (Fig. 2B). There was no stimulatory effect of overexpressing Ets-1 when VDRE-1 was mutated (Fig. 2B); however, over-coexpression of Ets-1 and hVDR increased 1,25D induction from 7.9- to 14.9-fold when analyzed in the presence of inactive VDRE-2 (Fig. 2B). The results demonstrate that the proximity of the EBS to VDRE-1 underlies its contribution to induction. Evidence for an in vivoprotein-protein interaction between Ets-1 and VDR was achieved using the mammalian two-hybrid assay and the plasmid G5E1B-Luc as reporter (Fig. 2C). The fusion protein GAL4-Ets-1 interacted substantially with VP16-VDR but did not interact with control VP16-T3R (Fig. 2C). A similar interaction was seen with GAL4-Ets-1T38A (results not shown). VDR and wild type and mutant Ets-1 interactions were unaltered by 1,25D treatment (Fig. 2C). It is evident from these experiments that the ligand-independent interaction between Ets-1 and VDR does not require the threonine 38 residue of Ets-1. In agreement with this observation, it has been shown from in vitro pull-down experiments that a region in the DNA binding domain of VDR interacts with an Ets-1 deletion protein that lacks threonine 38 (34). We have previously shown that overexpression of H-Ras in COS-1 cells increases 1,25D induction of the CYP24 promoter construct and that this action is potentiated in the presence of the wild type but not the mutant form Ets-1 (18Dwivedi P.P. Omdahl J.L. Kola I. Hume D.A. May B.K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 47-55Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). This implies that Ras plays a role in the 1,25D induction of the CYP24 promoter in COS-1 cells and that Ets-1 can positively modulate the action of Ras. To investigate the possible involvement of endogenous Ras activity, we have overexpressed an inhibitory dominant-negative rasconstruct, ras17N. Expression of Ras17N strongly reduced 1,25D induction of the pCYP24WT(−298)-Luc construct from 26- to 3.5-fold at the highest concentration tested. At these concentrations of Ras17N, there was no effect on basal expression of pCYP24WT(−298)-Luc or expression of the internal control pRL-TK-Luc described under “Experimental Procedures” (data not shown), demonstrating that Ras17N has a selective inhibitory effect on 1,25D induction. However, in the absence of Ras17N, mutagenesis of the EBS reduced 1,25D induction to 14.0-fold (Fig.3). These results not only demonstrate that Ras is essential for components of the 1,25D-responsive transcription machinery but also suggest that although the EBS is a downstream mediator site of Ras signaling, the action of Ras is also channeled through other downstream effectors. The extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase ERK1/ERK2 MAP kinases are major downstream effectors of Ras. Both MAP kinases are members of a cascade of kinases that consists of the MAP kinase kinase kinase, raf-1, which phosphorylates and activates the MAP kinase kinases, MEK1/MEK2, the immediate upstream regulators of ERK1/ERK2 (20Marshall C. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 732-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). To determine whether ERK1/ERK2 are involved in the actions of 1,25D, we first investigated whether 1,25D-stimulated the activities of ERK1/ERK2 in COS-1 cells. It is evident from the data in Fig.4A that 1,25D at 10−7m rapidly increased ERK1/ERK2 dual phosphorylation and hence activity. Although increased ERK1 phosphorylation persisted for at least 30 min, ERK2 phosphorylation peaked at 5 min after the addition of 1,25D. The effect of 1,25D on ERK1/ERK2 dual phosphorylation was also observed at 10−9but not at 10−10m (Fig. 4B). The precursor, 25D, at 10−7m did not affect ERK1/ERK2 phosphorylation (Fig.4B) nor induce pCYP24WT(−298)-Luc expression (data not shown) in which stimulation of MAP kinase was selective for 1,25D at a low concentration. Activation of ERK2 activity by 1,25D using myelin basic protein as a substrate was confirmed in cells that had been transfected with HA-ERK2 (Fig. 4C). Bop1 is a conserved nucleolar protein involved in rRNA processing and ribosome assembly in eukaryotes. Expression of its dominant-negative mutant Bop1Δ in mouse cells blocks rRNA maturation and synthesis of large ribosomal subunits and induces a reversible, p53-dependent cell cycle arrest. In this study, we have conducted a deletion analysis of Bop1 and identified a new mutant, Bop1N2, that also acts as a potent inhibitor of cell cycle progression. Bop1N2 and Bop1Δ are C-terminal and N-terminal deletion mutants, respectively, and share only 72 amino acid residues. Both mutant proteins are localized to the nucleolus and strongly inhibit rRNA processing, suggesting that activation of a cell cycle checkpoint by Bop1 mutants is linked to their inhibitory effects on rRNA and ribosome synthesis. By using these dominant-negative mutants as well as antisense oligonucleotides to interfere with endogenous Bop1, we identified specific rRNA processing steps that require Bop1 function in mammalian cells. Our data demonstrate that Bop1 is required for proper processing at four distinct sites located within the internal transcribed spacers ITS1 and ITS2 and the 3′ external spacer. We propose a model in which Bop1 serves as an essential factor in ribosome formation that coordinates processing of the spacer regions in pre-rRNA.

To determine whether reduction of insulin resistance could ameliorate fructose-induced very low density lipoprotein (VLDL) oversecretion and to explore the mechanism of this effect, fructose-fed hamsters received placebo or rosiglitazone for 3 weeks. Rosiglitazone treatment led to normalization of the blunted insulin-mediated suppression of the glucose production rate and to a ∼2-fold increase in whole body insulin-mediated glucose disappearance rate (p < 0.001). Rosiglitazone ameliorated the defect in hepatocyte insulin-stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of the insulin receptor, IRS-1, and IRS-2 and the reduced protein mass of IRS-1 and IRS-2 induced by fructose feeding. Protein-tyrosine phosphatase 1B levels were increased with fructose feeding and were markedly reduced by rosiglitazone. Rosiglitazone treatment led to a ∼50% reduction of VLDL secretion rates (p < 0.05)in vivo and ex vivo. VLDL clearance assessed directly in vivo was not significantly different in the FR (fructose-fed + rosiglitazone-treated) versus F (fructose-fed + placebo-treated) hamsters, although there was a trend toward a lower clearance with rosiglitazone. Enhanced stability of nascent apolipoprotein B (apoB) in fructose-fed hepatocytes was evident, and rosiglitazone treatment resulted in a significant reduction in apoB stability. The increase in intracellular mass of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein seen with fructose feeding was reduced by treatment with rosiglitazone. In conclusion, improvement of hepatic insulin signaling with rosiglitazone, a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ agonist, is associated with reduced hepatic VLDL assembly and secretion due to reduced intracellular apoB stability. Steiner G. Diabetes Metab. Rev. 1996; 12: 37-56Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Elevated plasma free fatty acid (FFA) flux from peripheral and intra-abdominal adipose tissue depots due to resistance to the insulin anti-lipolytic and esterification effect in adipose tissue is felt to play an important role in driving VLDL assembly and secretion in insulin resistant states (2Ginsberg H.N. J. Clin. Invest. 2000; 106: 453-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (916) Google Scholar, 3Lewis G.F. Carpentier A. Adeli K. Giacca A. Endocr. Rev. 2002; 23: 201-229Crossref PubMed Scopus (829) Google Scholar, 4Lewis G.F. Curr. Opin. Lipidol. 1997; 8: 146-153Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar). Nevertheless, previous studies in humans suggest that insulin also has an important direct effect on the liver in controlling VLDL secretion (5Lewis G.F. Uffelman K.D. Szeto L.W. Weller B. Steiner G. J. Clin. Invest. 1995; 95: 158-166Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Malmstrom R. Packard C.J. Caslake M. Bedford D. Stewart P. YkiJarvinen H. Shepherd J. Taskinen M.R. Diabetes. 1998; 47: 779-787Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar, 7Carpentier A. Patterson B.W. Uffelman K. Giacca A. Vranic M. Cattral M.S. Lewis G.F. Diabetes. 2001; 50: 1402-1413Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar).Rat and mouse models of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes have provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of insulin resistance. These animal models may not, however, be ideal for the study of human lipoprotein disorders because, unlike humans, their livers secrete both apoB48 and apoB100-containing VLDL, and they do not necessarily develop VLDL oversecretion as the basis for their hypertriglyceridemia (8Hirano T. Mamo J. Poapst M. Steiner G. Am. J. Physiol. 1988; 255: E236-E240PubMed Google Scholar, 9Li X. Grundy S.M. Patel S.B. J. Lipid Res. 1997; 38: 1277-1288Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Unlike livers from rat or mouse, the liver of the golden Syrian hamster secretes only apoB100-containing VLDL, and its lipoprotein metabolism more closely resembles that of humans (10Taghibiglou C. Rudy D. VanIderstine S.C. Aiton A. Cavallo D. Cheung R. Adeli K. J. Lipid Res. 2000; 41: 499-513Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We have shown that insulin resistance in the fructose-fed golden Syrian hamster is associated with mild hypertriglyceridemia, VLDL-apoB oversecretion, increased intracellular apoB-containing lipoprotein particle stability, and increased expression of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) (11Taghibiglou C. Carpentier A. Rudy D. Aiton A. Lewis G.F. Adeli K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 8416-8425Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). The present studies were conducted to explore the effect of improving insulin sensitivity in this insulin-resistant animal model by treatment with rosiglitazone, a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ agonist and insulin sensitizer and to gain further insight into the molecular mechanisms of VLDL oversecretion in insulin resistant states.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESAnimals and Study ProtocolsMale Syrian golden hamsters (Charles River, Quebec, Canada) were housed in pairs and given free access to food and water. After 7 days acclimatization, animals were placed on a fructose-enriched diet (hamster diet with 60% fructose, pelleted, Dyets Inc., Bethlehem, PA) for 5 weeks. After 2 weeks of feeding with the fructose-enriched diet, the animals were randomized to receive either rosiglitazone (20 μmol/kg/day) (GlaxoSmithKline) diluted in waterversus water only given once daily by gavage for the remaining 3 weeks of the fructose feeding period. At the end of the 5 weeks, the fructose-fed (F) and fructose-fed + rosiglitazone-treated (FR) animals underwent either one of the three in vivoprotocols described below or isolation of hepatocytes for the ex vivo protocols. In addition, some animals remained on regular chow for 5 weeks to serve as normal controls.In Vivo ProtocolsEuglycemic Hyperinsulinemic Clamp StudiesStudies were performed as previously described (11Taghibiglou C. Carpentier A. Rudy D. Aiton A. Lewis G.F. Adeli K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 8416-8425Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar) with the following modifications. Catheters were kept patent overnight with 4% heparin in normal saline (Hepalean, Organon Teknica, 1000 IU/ml). At 8:00 a.m. the morning after insertion of femoral vein and arterial catheters, a primed (10 μCi) constant (0.1 μCi/min) infusion of high performance liquid chromatography-purified [3-3H]glucose (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) was started (time, 90 min) (12Schwenk W.F. Butler P.C. Haymond M.W. Rizza R.A. Am. J. Physiol. 1990; 258: E228-E233PubMed Google Scholar). [3-3H]Glucose was added to the 20% dextrose infusate to minimize the decline in glucose specific activity during the clamp. After 75 min of equilibration at time 0 min, a primed (80 milliunits/kg) constant insulin infusion (8 milliunits/kg/min in 0.1% bovine serum albumin in normal saline) (Humulin R, Eli Lilly, Canada) was started, and a D20% infusion was adjusted at 10-min intervals to maintain blood glucose at base-line level. Blood samples (0.25 ml) were taken from the arterial line at times 15, 0, 90, 100, 110, and 120 min of the clamp for measurement of blood glucose, [3-3H]glucose specific activity (SA), and plasma insulin levels. There was no significant decline in hematocrit throughout the study. Endogenous glucose production (Ra) was calculated as the endogenous rate of appearance measured with [3-3H]glucose using a modified one-compartment model (13Finegood D.T. Bergman R.N. Vranic M. Diabetes. 1987; 36: 914-924Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Insulin-mediated glucose disappearance (ΔRd) was the rate of disappearance measured with [3-3H]glucose during the clamp minus the mean base-line Rd level. Data were smoothed with the optimal segments routine (14Finegood D.T. Bergman R.N. Am. J. Physiol. 1983; 244: E472-E479PubMed Google Scholar) using the optimal error algorithm (15Bradley D.C. Steil G.M. Bergman R.N. Am. J. Physiol. 1993; 264: E902-E911PubMed Google Scholar). Because euglycemia was not maintained in one hamster of the FR group, this animal was not included in the analysis of these experiments.In Vivo VLDL Secretion StudiesOne day before these studies, catheters were inserted into the femoral vein and artery of F (n = 10) and FR animals (n = 9) of similar weight (134 ± 3 g versus 132 ± 2 g, respectively, p = 0.64) and chow-fed controls (n = 5) as previously described (11Taghibiglou C. Carpentier A. Rudy D. Aiton A. Lewis G.F. Adeli K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 8416-8425Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). VLDL-apoB and VLDL-triglyceride (TG) secretion rates were measured in the fasting state (12 h) after intravenous injection of Triton WR-1339 (Sigma) as previously described (11Taghibiglou C. Carpentier A. Rudy D. Aiton A. Lewis G.F. Adeli K. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 8416-8425Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (266) Google Scholar). The total blood volume of the samples drawn was less than 1.5 ml per animal during the experiment, and there was no significant decline in hematocrit.In Vivo VLDL Clearance StudiesBecause the Triton method does not allow direct assessment of VLDL clearance, the following studies were performed after a 12-h fast in 7 F and 8 FR animals of similar weight (129 ± 6 g versus 126 ± 4 g, respectively, p = 0.68). Catheters were inserted the day before these studies into the femoral vein and artery. A bolus (20 μCi) of [2-3H]glycerol (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) was injected intravenously, and blood samples were collected at times 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, and 50 min after the injection to measure VLDL-TG levels and to determine the rate of decline of VLDL-TG [3-3H]glycerol SA. The fractional clearance rate of VLDL-TG (pool/min) was assessed by the slope of the natural logarithm of VLDL-TG [2-3H] glycerol SA over time, determined by linear regression over the linear portion of the down-slope, as previously described (16Lemieux S. Patterson B.W. Carpentier A. Lewis G.F. Steiner G. J. Lipid Res. 1999; 40: 2111-2117Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Ex Vivo ProtocolsLiver Perfusion and Isolation of Primary Hamster HepatocytesAfter an overnight fast, the liver of animals from the F and FR groups was perfused under anesthesia, and hepatocytes released from digested liver tissue were transferred into culture medium and seeded in collagen-coated plates as previously described (11Taghibiglou C. Carpentier A. Rudy D. Aiton A. Lewis G.F. Adeli K. J. Biol. For the euglycemic clamp studies, two-way analysis of variance was used to compare the glucose, insulin, Ra, and ΔRd curves of the F, FR, and control chow-fed groups at base line and during the last 30 min of the clamp, and the difference between the three groups was assessed by post-hoc analysis using Scheffe test. A two-tailed unpaired homoscedastic t test was used to compare all the other quantitative parameters between F and FR hamsters and between F and control chow-fed hamsters. The insulin levels (Fig. 1 B) were similar throughout the clamp in the F, FR, and the control chow-fed group. Glucose SA (not shown) remained constant in the last 30 min of the clamp in the three groups. The endogenous glucose production rate (Ra) (Fig. 1 C) was significantly higher in the Fversus FR animals at base line (80.6 ± 12.2versus 54.0 ± 11.1 μmol/kg/min, p < 0.001) and throughout the clamp (51.9 ± 14.3 versus10.7 ± 7.0 μmol/kg/min, p < 0.001). Treatment of the F animals with rosiglitazone resulted in normalization of Ra at base line and during the clamp (p = NSversus control chow-fed group) and also led to normalization of the level of suppression of Ra from base line (Ra was suppressed to 64.7 ± 15.6 of base line versus 19.1 ± 11.4versus 13.1 ± 8.4% of base line level during the clamp in the F, FR, and control chow-fed group respectively,p < 0.001 for the difference between F and the two other groups). The glucose infusion rate (not shown) was significantly lower in the F versus the FR group during the last 30 min of the clamp (64.7 ± 8.7 versus 121.7 ± 25.1 μmol/kg/min, p < 0.001). However, rosiglitazone treatment did not completely correct the glucose infusion rate and remained lower than the control chow-fed group (glucose infusion rate of control chow-fed group, 176.2 ± 3.0 μmol/kg/min,p < 0.001 versus FR group). Insulin receptor appears as a doublet on the gel. We have consistently observed this doublet in hamster hepatocytes. We do not believe that the second band is a result of degradation, since the addition of protease inhibitors does not prevent the detection of the doublet (data not shown). The elimination of mitotic kinase activity at the end of mitosis is essential for progression to the next stage of the eukaryotic cell cycle. In budding yeast, this process is controlled by a regulatory cascade called the mitotic exit network. Extensive genetic data indicate that mitotic exit network activity is determined by a GTP-binding protein, Tem1, and its putative regulators, Bub2, Bfa1, and Lte1. Here we describe the purification and in vitro activities of Tem1, Bub2, and Bfa1. We describe the nucleotide binding properties of Tem1 and characterize its intrinsic GTPase activity. The combination of Bfa1 and Bub2 acts as a two-component GTPase-activating protein for Tem1. In the absence of Bub2, Bfa1 inhibits the GTPase and GTP exchange activities of Tem1. This inhibition is elicited by either the N- or C-terminal regions of Bfa1, which also retain some ability to co-activate GTPase activity in the presence of Bub2. Although the C-terminal region of Bfa1 binds to Bub2, no interaction of the N-terminal half of Bfa1 with Bub2 was detected despite their combined GAP activity. Therefore, we propose that Bfa1 acts both as an adaptor to connect Bub2 and Tem1 and as an allosteric effector that facilitates this interaction. The combination of Bfa1 and Bub2 acts as a two-component GTPase-activating protein for Tem1. In the absence of Bub2, Bfa1 inhibits the GTPase and GTP exchange activities of Tem1. This inhibition is elicited by either the N- or C-terminal regions of Bfa1, which also retain some ability to co-activate GTPase activity in the presence of Bub2. Although the C-terminal region of Bfa1 binds to Bub2, no interaction of the N-terminal half of Bfa1 with Bub2 was detected despite their combined GAP activity. Therefore, we propose that Bfa1 acts both as an adaptor to connect Bub2 and Tem1 and as an allosteric effector that facilitates this interaction. mitotic exit network GTPase-activating protein Bfa1 full-length Bfa1 N-terminal residues 1–302 Bfa1 C-terminal residues 294–574 septation initiation network maltose-binding protein glutathioneS-transferase In the final phases of eukaryotic cell division, the duplicated chromosomes and the centrosomes are partitioned between the dividing cells. Only then does the final step of cell separation occur, thus avoiding chromosomal loss or gain from precocious cell division or misaligned spindles. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, this sequence of mitotic exit and cytokinesis is controlled by a signal transduction cascade called the mitotic exit network (MEN)1 (reviewed in Refs. 1Bardin A.J. Amon A. Nature Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2001; 2: 815-826Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar and 2McCollum D. Gould K.L. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 89-95Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (219) Google Scholar). The primary role of the MEN is to reduce mitotic kinase activity, a prerequisite for spindle disassembly and cytokinesis. The MEN comprises a regulatory cascade with the small Ras-like protein, Tem1 (3Shirayama M. Matsui Y. Toh-e A. Mol. Cell Biol. 1994; 14: 7476-7482Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar), and its putative regulators, Bfa1, Bub2 and Lte1, at the top of the pathway (4Shirayama M. Matsui Y. Tanaka K. Toh-e A. Yeast. 1994; 4: 451-461Crossref Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 5Jaspersen A.L. Charles J.F. Tinker-Kulberg R.L. Morgan D.O. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1998; 9: 2803-2817Crossref PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar, 6Lee S.E. Jensen S. Frenz L.M. Johnson A.L. Fesquet D. Johnston L.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2345-2354PubMed Google Scholar). Other components are the kinases Cdc15, Cdc5, Dbf2, and Dbf20. Also involved are the Dbf2-associated protein Mob1, the phosphatase Cdc14, and Nud1, a spindle pole body component important for proper localization of other MEN proteins (reviewed in Refs. 1Bardin A.J. Amon A. Nature Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 2001; 2: 815-826Crossref PubMed Scopus (291) Google Scholar and 2McCollum D. Gould K.L. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 89-95Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (219) Google Scholar). Recent data suggest that the functional sequence of the MEN components is Tem1-Cdc15-Mob1/Dbf2-Cdc14 (7Lee S.E. Frenz L.M. Wells N.J. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 784-788Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). The role of the Cdc5 kinase is less clear, and it probably acts at different steps as a positive and/or negative regulator. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2345-2354PubMed Google Scholar). DespiteTEM1 being an essential gene, BUB2,BFA1, and LTE1 are dispensable in an unperturbed cell cycle. Frenz L.M. Johnson A.L. Fesquet D. Johnston L.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2345-2354PubMed Google Scholar). It has been proposed that during mitosis, the migration of the spindle pole bodies into the daughter cell, where Lte1 is primarily localized, triggers the activation of the MEN. MEN activation has also been related to the phosphorylation of Bfa1. Bfa1 is a substrate for Cdc5 and Cdc28 kinases, and its pattern of phosphorylation is determined by cell cycle phase and spindle status (6Lee S.E. Jensen S. Frenz L.M. Johnson A.L. Fesquet D. The homologues of most of the components of the MEN can be found in the SIN indicating that the two pathways are operationally similar. In the SIN, Spg1 is the homologue of Tem1. Both proteins belong to the Ras superfamily of small GTPases and share 58% sequence identity. In vivo, the down-regulation of Spg1 is achieved by Cdc16 and Byr4 (23Minet M. Nurse P. Thuriaux P. Mitchison J. J. Bacteriol. 1979; 137: 440-446Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 24Song K. Mach K.E. Chen C.Y. Reynolds T. Albright C.F. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 1307-1319Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar), which have been shown in vitro to act together as a two-component GTPase-activating protein (GAP) (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). Bub2 and Bfa1 are homologous to Cdc16 and Byr4 and, on this basis, have also been considered as a two-component GAP of Tem1. The activation of Tem1 is thought to be carried out by Lte1, which contains a Cdc25 nucleotide exchange factor homology domain in its C terminus (4Shirayama M. Matsui Y. Tanaka K. Toh-e A. Yeast. 1994; 4: 451-461Crossref Scopus (87) Google Scholar). Despite this similarity between the components of the MEN and SIN, TEM1 and BFA1cannot complement spg1 or byr4 mutations, respectively (26Schmidt S. Sohrmann M. Hofmann K. Woollard A. Simanis V. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1519-1534Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 27Lee J. Hwang H-S. Kim J. Song K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1999; 1449: 239-253Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Moreover, no positive regulator of the Spg1 GTP cycle has yet been identified. Despite the extensive genetic, cellular, and physiological data available concerning the roles of Bub2, Bfa1, and Lte1, no biochemical characterization of their in vitro activities has been carried out. Likewise, no data exist on the properties of Tem1 with the exception of its ability to bind GTP (3Shirayama M. Matsui Y. Toh-e A. Mol. Cell Biol. 1994; 14: 7476-7482Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar). Here, we characterize the enzymatic activity of Tem1 and show that Bfa1 and Bub2 act together as a two-component GAP. Furthermore, our data suggest that Bfa1 might induce a conformational change in Tem1 in addition to acting as the bridge between Tem1 and Bub2. The TEM1 open reading frame was amplified by PCR using a 5′-oligonucleotide containing aBamHI site and a 3′-oligonucleotide containing anHindIII site and was ligated into pMAL-c2X (New England Biolabs) yielding pMAL-Tem1. BFA1 was amplified by PCR using a 5′-oligonucleotide with a BamHI site and a 3′-oligonucleotide containing a XbaI site and was ligated into pGEX-KG yielding pGEX-Bfa1. pGEX-Bfa1 was then digested withBamHI and XhoI and a Bfa-containing fragment was cloned into pMAL-c2X digested with BamHI and SalI enzymes to obtain pMAL-Bfa1FL. The sequence encoding the 280 C-terminal residues 294–574 of Bfa1was amplified by PCR using a 5′-oligonucleotide containing a BamHI site and a 3′-oligonucleotide containing a XhoI site and was cloned into pMAL-c2X cut with BamHI and SalI enzymes to obtain pMAL-Bfa1CT. The sequence encoding the first 302 N-terminal residues of Bfa1 was amplified by PCR using a 5′-oligonucleotide with aBamHI site and a 3′-oligonucleotide containing anHindIII site and was cloned into pMAL-c2X to obtain pMAL-Bfa1NT. The BUB2 open reading frame was amplified by PCR using a 5′-oligonucleotide containing a SmaI site and a 3′-oligonucleotide containing a XbaI site and was ligated into pGEX-KG to give pGEX-Bub2. Escherichia coliBL21 containing expression plasmids for MBP-Tem1, MBP-Bfa1 full-length, MBP-Bfa1CT, MBP-Bfa1NT, GST, and GST-Bub2 were grown in LB broth at 37 °C for 3 h, transferred to 25 °C, and after 1 h were induced with 0.1 mmisopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside for 2 h. Cells expressing the MBP-Tem1 fusion protein were resuspended in cold lysis buffer (50 mm Hepes, pH 7.0, 200 mm NaCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 4 mm dithiothreitol, 1 mm benzamidine, and 4 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and passed through a French press. MBP-Tem1 fusion protein was purified by affinity chromatography as recommended by the manufacturer (New England Biolabs). The eluted protein was cut with Factor Xa (New England Biolabs) overnight at 4 °C, and Tem1 was separated from MBP by ion exchange chromatography on SP-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) and stored at −80 °C. For Bfa1 and Bub2 fusion proteins, induced cells were lysed in cold lysis buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 200 mm NaCl, 2 mm DTT, and 4 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) and purified using amylose resin (New England Biolabs) or glutathione-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences). After elution, GST-Bub2 was dialyzed against 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 100 mm NaCl, 2 mm dithiothreitol, and 50% glycerol and stored at −20 °C. MBP-Bfa1 fusion proteins were stored at −80 °C. Glutathione beads with immobilized GST or GST-Bub2 (4 μg of each) were washed twice with binding buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 200 mm NaCl, and 1 mm dithiothreitol), resuspended in 250 μl of binding buffer plus 2% nonfat dry milk and protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Molecular Biochemical), and incubated with MBP-Bfa1 full-length, MBP-Bfa1CT, or MBP-Bfa1NT at a final concentration of ∼2 μm for 1.5 h at 4 °C. The beads were washed four times with binding buffer plus 0.5% Nonidet P-40, resuspended in binding buffer plus 15 mm of reduced glutathione, and incubated at room temperature for 15 min. The eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and analyzed by Western blotting with anti-MBP antibodies (New England Biolabs). 1 μg of purified Tem1 was incubated in 25 μl of loading buffer (20 mmTris-HCl, pH 7.5, 25 mm, NaCl, 5 mmMgCl2, and 0.1 mm DTT) containing 0.1 MBq of [γ-32P]GTP or 0.03 MBq of [γ-35S]GTP for 10 min at 30 °C. For GDP exchange, we used 5 μg of purified Tem1 and 0.1 MBq of [3H]GDP. The mixture was then put on ice, and 10 μl were added to 50 μl of reaction buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 2 mm GTP, and 0.6 μg/μl BSA). The tube was transferred at 30 °C, and at the indicated times, 10 μl of the reaction was diluted in 990 μl of cold washing buffer (20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 50 mm NaCl, and 5 mm MgCl2). The samples were filtered through prewetted nitrocellulose filters, washed three times with 4 ml of cold of washing buffer and air-dried. The amount of filter-bound radioactive nucleotide was determined by scintillation counting. When Bfa1 activity was examined, the indicated amount of purified Bfa1 was added to the loading buffer. When Bub2 activity was assessed, the indicated amount of purified Bub2 was added to the reaction buffer. The GDP and GTP dissociation rates, k d andk t, were calculated by a fit of the experimental data to a single exponential decay. Data points represent the average of at least two assays, which typically differed by < 10%. However, we have noticed that there was a certain degree of quantitative variation from experiment to experiment because of GTPase instability on filters. A similar phenomenon has been previously reported for Sec4 and Ran (28Kabcenell A.K. Goud B. Northup J.K. Novick P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9366-9372Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29Bischoff F.R. Krebber H. Smirnova E. Dong W. Ponstingl H. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 705-715Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar). To examine the properties of Tem1 and its putative regulators, Bfa1 and Bub2, all three proteins were expressed in E. coli and purified by affinity chromatography. Tem1 was expressed as an MBP-fusion protein, which was soluble in E. coli extracts. Following the removal of the affinity tag by Factor Xa, Tem1 was purified on SP-Sepharose to >95% homogeneity as judged by SDS-PAGE (Fig.1 A). Bub2, Bfa1, and the fragments thereof were expressed as GST and MBP fusion proteins, respectively, and were used without further removal of the affinity tag. Full-length Bfa1 and the N-terminal fragment migrate more slowly in SDS-PAGE than predicted by their calculated molecular weights. GST-Bub2 co-purified with a 60-kDa protein, which is likely to be the chaperone GroEL that has previously been reported to co-purify with Cdc16 (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). The induction of GST-Bub2 expression at 14 °C overnight did not reduce the apparent ratio between the chaperone and Bub2 but significantly increased its activity. To characterize the GTPase activity of Tem1, the rates of GTP hydrolysis and nucleotide dissociation were determined in a filter binding assay. Radiolabeled nucleotides were bound to Tem1. After 10 min, an excess of non-radioactive nucleotide was added, and a loss of radioactivity was measured over 30 min. With Tem1-[γ-32P]GTP, radioactivity is lost by two means, 1) by dissociation of GTP at a rate, k d, and 2) by hydrolysis and subsequent release of [γ-32P] at a rate, k hyd. Therefore, the kinetics of loss of counts from Tem1-[γ-32P]GTP are the sum of k dand k hyd and occurred with a rate of 0.19 min−1 at 30 °C (Fig. 2). To determine the rate of GTP dissociation alone, the non-hydrolyzable GTP analogue [γ-35S]GTP was used. In this case, [γ-35S]GTP was lost from Tem1 at ak d of 0.07 min−1 (Fig. 2). Finally, the dissociation of GDP was assayed using Tem1 loaded with [3H]GDP. Initial attempts to determine the rate for GDP dissociation at 30 °C proved difficult, because almost all of the [3H]GDP bound to Tem1 was lost within the first sampling interval. Carrying out the reaction at the lower temperature of 13 °C allowed us to determine a rate of 0.2 min−1 (Fig.2). This high rate of intrinsic GDP release may explain why the putative guanine nucleotide exchange factor, Lte1, is not an essential protein at least at 30 °C. Even without Lte1, there might be sufficient intrinsic exchange activity to provide enough Tem1-GTP for MEN activation. Byr4, the S. pombehomologue of Bfa1, inhibits both GTP dissociation and GTP hydrolysis by Spg1 (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). To test whether Bfa1 might have similar properties, we monitored the intrinsic GTPase activity of Tem1 and nucleotide dissociation in the presence of varying amounts of Bfa1. For this test, Tem1 was loaded with radioactive nucleotides and incubated for times and temperatures that gave an ∼50% loss of label as shown in Fig. 2. The effect of Bfa1 on GTP dissociation was assayed using Tem1 loaded with [γ-35S]GTP. Whereas 45% of radiolabel was released during the subsequent incubation period in the absence of Bfa1, this release was progressively inhibited by increasing amounts of Bfa1. Thus, Bfa1 inhibits GTP dissociation from Tem1. Likewise, the effect of Bfa1 on GTP hydrolysis was monitored with Tem1 loaded with [γ-32P]GTP. Again, there was a strong Bfa1-dependent inhibition of loss of radioactivity from Tem1-[γ-32P]GTP indicating the inhibition of GTP hydrolysis by Bfa1 (Fig. 3). Dissociation and hydrolysis of GTP were fully inhibited at concentrations of ∼200 nm Bfa1, suggesting that the affinity between Tem1 and Bfa1 is high with a dissociation constant in the low nanomolar range. In contrast, Bfa1 does not markedly affect the dissociation of GDP from Tem1 as judged by the similar losses of radiolabeled [3H]GDP in the presence or absence of Bfa1 (Fig. 3) Although Bub2 and Cdc16 contain a TBC homology domain (domain in Tre-2, BUB2p, and Cdc16p) typical of GAPs for Rab-like GTPases (30Neuwald A.F. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 243-244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar), the Bub2 homologue, Cdc16, only displays GAP activity in combination with Byr4 (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). To test whether Bub2 might have a similar activity, Tem1 was loaded with [γ-32P]GTP in the presence or absence of Bfa1. After loading, increasing amounts of Bub2 were added, and the fraction of [γ-32P]GTP remaining bound to Tem1 after a 7-min incubation at 30 °C was compared with levels bound at time zero (Fig.4 A). In the absence of Bfa1 or Bub2, ∼50% of the radioactive [γ-32P]GTP bound to Tem1 was lost. This reflects the intrinsic GTP dissociation and GTPase activities of Tem1 as described above (Fig. 2). Notably, in the absence of Bfa1, there were no further changes in bound [γ-32P]GTP upon the addition of increasing amounts of Bub2, clearly indicating that Bub2 alone does not affect either hydrolysis or dissociation of GTP from Tem1. In parallel assays increasing amounts of Bub2 were added to Tem1-[γ-32P]GTP in the presence of a fixed concentration of Bfa1. In the zero Bub2 control, there was no loss of [γ-32P]GTP from Tem1, a result already seen above in which Bfa1 alone inhibits the GTP hydrolysis and GTP dissociation (Fig.3). However, the addition of Bub2 in the presence of Bfa1 caused a precipitous loss of radioactivity from Tem1-[γ-32P]GTP (Fig. 4 A). To ensure that this loss of radioactivity was attributed to GTP hydrolysis and not because of an increased rate of GTP dissociation, we performed a similar assay with [γ-35S]GTP (Fig. 4 B). The addition of Bub2 caused no loss of the non-hydrolyzable [γ-35S]GTP from Tem1 with or without accompanying Bfa1. The amount of Bub2 required to achieve maximal stimulation of GAP activity is significantly higher than the amount of Bfa1 required for complete inhibition of GTP hydrolysis and dissociation (Fig. 4 A). At present, we are not able to conclude whether this reflects a real difference in the affinities between these complexes or whether only a fraction of the Bub2 used in these assays is fully active, possibly because of the association with GroEL. The GAP-activated GTPase activity of Tem1 in the presence of 150 nm Bfa1 and 15 μm Bub2 is shown in Fig. 4 C in comparison to its intrinsic GTPase activity. Under these conditions, hydrolysis is complete after 5 min. As expected from Fig. 3, the presence of 150 nm Bfa1 alone caused a large reduction in the kinetics of GTP hydrolysis by Tem1. The results presented thus far show that Bfa1 has different activities depending upon the absence or presence of Bub2. Without Bub2, Bfa1 inhibits GTP hydrolysis and GTP dissociation from Tem, whereas it acts as a two-component GAP in the presence of Bub2. To characterize these different effects of Bfa1 in more detail and to map the regions that are responsible for these activities, we produced an N-terminal fragment of Bfa1, Bfa1NT encompassing residues 1–302 and a C-terminal fragment Bfa1CT encompassing residues 294–574. These fragments were expressed as MBP fusion proteins and purified from E. coli(Fig. 1 B, lanes 2 and 3, respectively). Both fragments were tested for their effect on GTP dissociation and GTPase hydrolysis of Tem1. For this test, increasing amounts of Bfa1NT, Bfa1CT, and full-length Bfa1 were added to Tem1 during loading with [γ-32P]GTP and the time course of loss of radioactivity was measured (Fig.5). In the absence of Bfa1, only 50% [γ-32P] GTP remained bound to Tem1 after 5 min because of GTP dissociation and GTP hydrolysis (see Fig. 2). Also, as expected from Fig. 3, 200 nm full-length Bfa1 prevented all loss of [γ-32P]GTP. As shown in Fig. 5, both Bfa1NT and Bfa1CT inhibit GTP hydrolysis by Tem1. Bfa1CT shows similar concentration dependence as the full-length protein, indicating that both proteins bind Tem1 with equal affinities. In contrast, slightly higher concentrations of Bfa1NT are required to achieve a similar effect. We have also observed that GST-Bfa1NT and GST-Bfa1CT have the same inhibitory effects on GTP hydrolysis and exchange in Tem1 as do the equivalent MBP fusions (data not shown). Thus, the MBP moiety does not inhibit Tem1 activity, nor does the type of tag modify the activity of the Bfa1 fusion proteins. Next we investigated whether both of these two fragments can interact with Bub2 to form a two-component GAP for Tem1. The concentration dependence of Bub2 on GAP activity with full-length Bfa1 (150 nm) is shown in Fig. 6. More than 95% GTP is hydrolyzed after 7 min in the presence of 30 μm Bub2. Bfa1CT is also capable of stimulating GTP hydrolysis, although 3–4 times higher amounts of Bub2 are required to achieve maximal activity. The Bfa1NT was also able to increase GTP hydrolysis in combination with Bub2, yet this fragment showed a significantly lower activity than the C-terminal part of the protein. Thus, the N-terminal as well as the C-terminal fragments of Bfa1 can act as a two-component GAP with Bub2, although there is a significant difference in their activity at identical Bub2 concentrations. To investigate whether the differences in GAP activity between the N- and C-terminal portions of Bfa1 are caused by their different affinities for Bub2, we carried out in vitro pull-down binding assays. GST-Bub2 or a GST control were bound to glutathione-sepharose beads and assayed for their ability to bind to Bfa1NT, Bfa1CT, or full-length Bfa1 (Fig.7). Approximately, equal amounts of each form of Bfa1 were used as judged by Western blotting with an anti-MBP antibody. Only full-length Bfa1 and Bfa1CT bound to the GST-Bub2 beads. Indeed, the Bfa1CT seemed to bind more effectively to Bub2 than the full-length protein. No binding was detected with Bfa1NT, indicating both that this portion of Bfa1 does not interact with Bub2, and more generally, that binding is not caused by the MBP moiety of any of the Bfa1 fusion proteins used in these assays. No form of Bfa1 bound to the control GST-only beads. The minor high molecular weight bands retained by GST-Bub2 and MBP-Bfa1CT are probably unspecific bands attributed to the milk used in the binding assay. To avoid the possibility that immobilizing Bub2 on beads may in some way interfere with the interaction with Bfa1NT, a second series of binding assays were performed with immobilized Bfa1 and free Bub2. MBP, MBP-Bfa1NT, MBP-Bfa1CT, and MBP-Bfa1FL were immobilized on amylose resin and assayed for binding in vitro transcribed and translated [35S]Bub2 (data not shown). These experiments confirmed that only full-length Bfa1 and Bfa1CT interact specifically with Bub2. The activation of the mitotic exit network by Tem1 and its regulation by Bub2/Bfa1 has been the subject of intense analysis for several years. Here, we describe the purification and enzymatic activities of Tem1, Bub2, and Bfa1. We show that Tem1 is a GTPase, which is down-regulated by a two-component GAP comprising Bub2 and Bfa1. The negative regulation of mitotic exit by Bub2/Bfa1 in vivo can therefore be attributed to their ability to activate GTP hydrolysis and thereby reduce the active form of Tem1 until the spindle is correctly assembled and positioned for the even partitioning of chromosomes. The rates of GTP dissociation and GTP hydrolysis of Tem1 are very similar to those determined for its S. pombe homologue Spg1 and those of members of the Rho family of small GTPases (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar, 31Neal S.E. Eccleston J.F. Hall A. Webb M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 19718-19722Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32Leonard D.A. Evans T. Hart M. Cerione R.A. Manor D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12323-12328Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 33Self A.J. Hall A. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 256: 67-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). As bfa1 and bub2 mutants are viable and grow at normal rates, the intrinsic GTPase activity of Tem1 may be sufficient for the correct execution of mitotic exit, at least in the absence of spindle damage. In contrast to GTP dissociation, the release of GDP from Tem1 and Spg1 is significantly faster than for many other small GTPases. The only other example of a GTPase with a comparatively high GDP off-rate is Sec4, which belongs to the Rab family of small GTPases (28Kabcenell A.K. Goud B. Northup J.K. Novick P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9366-9372Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). From the crystal structure of this protein, it has been suggested that differences in the switch regions might weaken Mg2+binding and thereby cause the high GDP off-rate (34Stroupe C. Brunger A.T. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 304: 585-598Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). Similar structural features may be the reason for the high rate of GDP dissociation observed for Tem1 and Spg1. However, the confirmation of this notion or otherwise awaits the structural characterization of Tem1 and Spg1. Nevertheless, the high GDP exchange rate is consistent with the observation that Lte1, the putative exchange factor for Tem1, is not essential at least at 30 °C (4Shirayama M. Matsui Y. Tanaka K. Toh-e A. Yeast. 1994; 4: 451-461Crossref Scopus (87) Google Scholar). Presumably, inlte1 mutants, the high intrinsic exchange activity can maintain adequate levels of Tem1-GTP for mitotic exit. Bub2 contains a TBC domain that is the signature motif for GAPs specific for Rab-like small GTPases (30Neuwald A.F. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1997; 22: 243-244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). GAPs for small GTPases are typically monomeric proteins that are able to increase the intrinsic GTPase rate by several orders of magnitude by a mechanism that often involves the stabilization of the switch regions of the GTPase and the supply of a catalytic residue into the active site of the GTPase (reviewed in Refs. 35Scheffzek K. Ahmadian M.R. Wittinghofer A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1998; 23: 257-262Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (347) Google Scholar and 36Gamblin S.J. Smerdon S.J. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1998; 8: 195-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). Yet, despite the presence of a GAP homology domain, Bub2 has an absolute requirement for Bfa1 as a co-activator of GAP activity. The only other system identified so far in which two proteins are required to form a functional GAP is the SIN, which is regulated by the small GTPase, Spg1, and its two-component GAP, Cdc16/Byr4 (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). In vitro results from the two systems suggest two roles for Bfa1 and Byr4 in bringing about co-activation. Firstly, the results presented here and by Furgeet al. (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar) suggest that Bfa1 and Byr4 have a “bridging” role in the GTPase·GAP complex. Byr4 can interact with both Spg1 and Cdc16, but Spg1 and Cdc16 do not stably interact without Byr4. Similarly, we show that Bfa1 interacts with both Tem1 and Bub2. Bfa1 contacts Bub2 via its C-terminal region whereas both the N- and C-terminal portions of Bfa1 can contact Tem1 as judged by the inhibition of GTPase and GTP dissociation. A similar distribution of the binding regions was found in Byr4 (37Furge K.A. Cheng Q. Jwa M. Shin S. Song K. Albright C.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 11339-11343Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). In GAP assays, it was largely the Bfa1 C-terminal region with its ability to interact with both Bub2 and Tem1 that supported GAP activity. Thus, Bfa1 like Byr4 might serve as an adaptor to connect Bub2 and Tem1. However, several observations suggest that Bfa1 might have an additional function. Bfa1 is subject to cell cycle and spindle damage-dependent fluctuations in phosphorylation that have been related to alterations in GAP activity (6Lee S.E. Jensen S. Frenz L.M. Johnson A.L. Fesquet D. Johnston L.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2345-2354PubMed Google Scholar, 20Hu F. Wang Y. Liu D. Li Y. Qin J. Elledge S.J. Cell. 2001; 107: 1-20Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). Furthermore, Bfa1 and its N- or C-terminal fragments are able to inhibit GTP hydrolysis and GTP dissociation of Tem1. This activity is reminiscent of guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors and certain downstream effectors, which have previously been shown to inhibit GTP hydrolysis and/or nucleotide dissociation (38Chuang T.H. Xu X. Knaus U.G. Hart M.J. Bokoch G.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 775-778Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 39Herrmann C. Horn G. Spaargaren M. Wittinghofer A. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 71: 6794-6800Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (298) Google Scholar, 40Nomanbhoy T.K. Cerione R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10004-10009Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar, 41Rudolph M.G. Bayer P. Abo A. Kuhlmann J. Vetter I.R. Wittinghofer A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 18067-18076Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar). In addition, the N-terminal fragment of Bfa1, which is unable to bind Bub2, is still able to act as a GAP in combination with Bub2, albeit at higher concentrations. Thus, the binding of Bfa1NT might be capable of inducing a conformational change in Tem1, which results in the formation of a binding site for Bub2. This suggestion is further supported by the reduced activity of the C-terminal portion of Bfa1 in promoting GAP activity compared with full-length Bfa1 (Fig. 6) despite the apparent higher affinity of Bfa1CT for Bub2 (Fig. 7). Together, these observations point to the C-terminal portion of Bfa1 acting as an adaptor to connect Bub2 and Tem1, whereas the N-terminal portion may modify the conformation of Tem1, thereby creating a binding site for Bub2. An example for the latter activity has been shown for Ran whose GTPase activity is enhanced by a combination of RanGAP and RanBP1 (29Bischoff F.R. Krebber H. Smirnova E. Dong W. Ponstingl H. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 705-715Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar). Although RanBP1 is not absolutely required for RanGAP activity, its presence increases the rate of GTP hydrolysis by an order of magnitude (29Bischoff F.R. Krebber H. Smirnova E. Dong W. Ponstingl H. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 705-715Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar). The structure of a trimeric complex between Ran, RanBP1, and RanGAP shows that there is no direct contact between RanGAP and RanBP1, making it unlikely that RanBP1 has a direct structural effect on RanGAP (42Seewald M.J. Korner C. Wittinghofer A. Vetter I.R. Nature. 2002; 415: 662-666Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). Instead, it appears that RanBP1 relieves a conformation of Ran, which is inhibitory to RanGAP binding. Given the role of Bfa1 in acting with Bub2 to reduce Tem1-GTP levels, it is paradoxical that Bfa1 acting without Bub2 maintains levels of Tem1-GTP. From this result, it might naively be predicted that the overexpression of Bfa1 would activate the MEN. However, the opposite occurs, and Bfa1 overexpression causes an anaphase arrest (15Li R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 4989-4994Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar), likewise the overexpression of Byr4 inhibits septation in S. pombe (23Minet M. Nurse P. Thuriaux P. Mitchison J. J. Bacteriol. 1979; 137: 440-446Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). This lethal Byr4/Bfa1 overexpression phenotype can be suppressed by co-overexpression of Spg1/Tem1 (25Furge K.A. Wong K. Armstrong J. Balasubramanian M. Albright C.F. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 947-954Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). 2M. Geymonat, unpublished observation. Thus, a high ratio of Bfa1 to Tem1 could inhibit the ability of Tem1-GTP to communicate with its effectors by competing for a common binding site on Tem1. As Tem1 requires a two-component GAP to restrain its activity, the ability of Bfa1 alone to block the activity of GTP-bound Tem1 therefore may provide a second tier of restraint to protect against precocious MEN activation. Although an interaction between Bub2 and Bfa1 has been seen throughout mitosis (6Lee S.E. Jensen S. Frenz L.M. Johnson A.L. Fesquet D. Johnston L.H. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 2345-2354PubMed Google Scholar), it is unclear whether all or just a proportion of Bfa1 and Bub2 are combined in this way. Therefore, the inhibitory effect of Bfa1 on Tem1 may safeguard against times when GAP activity is reduced by Bfa1 and Bub2 dissociation or by transiently low levels of Bub2. In summary, we present the first demonstration of the in vitro activities of Tem1 and their regulation by a GAP activity provided by a complex between Bub2 and Bfa1. Why such a complicated two-component GAP mechanism has evolved when most other small GTPases rely on monomeric GAPs remains an enigma. As a first step to answering this question, we present insights into the nature of Bub2 and Bfa1 interactions with each other and with Tem1. This work therefore provides the foundations for future investigations of how Bub2 and Bfa1 function as “gatekeepers” of the mitotic exit network. We thank Sanne Jensen and Geoffroy de Bettignies for help, advice, and encouragement. We also thank Barry Ely for help with early attempts at protein expression.

Steroid hormones exert genotropic actions through members of the nuclear receptor family. Here, we have demonstrated genotropic actions of testosterone that are independent of intracellular androgen receptors (iAR). Through plasma membrane androgen receptors (mAR), testosterone induces a rapid rise in the intracellular free Ca2+ concentration of iAR-free murine RAW 264.7 macrophages. This nongenomic testosterone signaling, which is independent of both iAR and estrogen receptors, does not in itself activate either the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) families ERK1/2, p38, and JNK/SAPK, the stably and transiently transfected c-fos promoter, or NO production. In the context of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) signaling, however, testosterone attenuates LPS activation of the c-fos promoter and NO production, which is abolished by the intracellular Ca2+chelator BAPTA. Testosterone also attenuates the LPS activation of p38 but not that of ERK1/2 and JNK/SAPK, and this attenuation is abrogated by BAPTA. Moreover, the p38 inhibitor, SB 203580, largely reduces LPS activation of the c-fos promoter and NO production, and the remaining levels are no longer regulated by testosterone. This study is the first to provide information on genotropic actions of mAR-mediated nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling by cross-talk with the LPS signaling pathway through p38 MAPK with impact on cell function. However, the functional importance of testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling, in particular with regard to gene expression and cell function, is not yet understood.To get information for possible genotropic effects of nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling, we have chosen as a model system mouse RAW 264.7 macrophages transiently or stably transfected with a c-fos promoter linked to human secreted alkaline phosphatase (SEAP) as a reporter, because the immediate early gene c-fos is known to be Ca2+-sensitive (31Roche E. Here, we have demonstrated that testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling through mAR cannot directly activate the c-fos promoter. However, nongenomic testosterone signaling is able to exert genotropic actions in context with the LPS signaling pathway through p38 MAPK with impact on cell function.DISCUSSIONNongenomic actions of steroids on cells are obviously much more complex than anticipated to date. During recent years, a number of reports have appeared describing nongenomic steroid effects that are mediated through the classic intracellular steroid receptors. Cell. 1999; 10: 3113-3123Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar, 30Wunderlich F. Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Guo Z. Stamm O. Wrehlke C. Sekeris C.E. Mossmann H. Nevertheless, in RAW 264.7 macrophages, testosterone is able to induce iAR-independent nongenomic actions, which can in turn even exert genotropic actions with impact on cell function.Nongenomic testosterone signaling manifests itself as a rapid rise in [Ca2+]i in macrophages of the cell line RAW 264.7. Such rises have also been observed in other cell types (26Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Sekeris C.E. Wunderlich F. Biochem. 1996; 61: 619-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). In RAW 264.7 cells, similar to IC-21 macrophages (29Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Stamm O. Wrehlke C. Guo Z. Wunderlich F. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 3113-3123Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar,30Wunderlich F. Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Guo Z. Stamm O. Wrehlke C. Sekeris C.E. Mossmann H. Steroids. 2002; 67: 535-538Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar), the testosterone-induced rise in [Ca2+]i is not prevented by the iAR blocker, cyproterone. We can also exclude the possible action of testosterone through the iER (24Kousteni S. Bellido T. Plotkin L.I. O'Brien C.A. Bodenner D.L. Han L. Han K. DiGregorio G.B. Katzenellenbogen J.A. Katzenellenbogen B.S. Roberson P.K. Weinstein R.S. Jilka R.L. Manolagas S.C. Cell. 2001; 104: 719-730Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) because the Ca2+ response was not sensitive to the iER blockers, raloxifene, tamoxifen, and ICI 182,780. Rather, our data demonstrate that testosterone exerts its nongenomic iAR- and iER-independent effects through mAR. An increase in [Ca2+]i is also inducible with the plasma membrane-impermeable testosterone-BSA, and specific binding sites for testosterone can be localized on the surface of intact RAW-fos13 cells with testosterone-BSA conjugated to FITC. Though still unknown in molecular terms, the mAR mediate actions specific for different androgens; only testosterone and 5α-DHT induce about the same rise in [Ca2+]i, whereas 5β-DHT and 1-DeHT are ineffective in evoking changes in [Ca2+]i of RAW-fos13 macrophages.The nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling through mAR is not able in itself to induce genotropic actions in terms of activation of the stably and transiently transfected promoter of the Ca2+-inducible gene c-fos in RAW 264.7 cells. Nevertheless, the nongenomic testosterone signaling has the potency to induce genotropic actions. This becomes evident in the context of co-stimulation of the LPS signaling pathway. Thus, LPS stimulates c-fos promoter activation, and this stimulation is attenuated by testosterone-induced Ca2+ signaling. This attenuation can be completely abolished by BAPTA, and it is specific as supported by the following results. First, E2 causes the opposite effect of testosterone, namely an enhanced activation of thec-fos promoter following LPS stimulation. Second, testosterone has no effect on SV40 promoter activity. Third, 5α-DHT is just as effective as testosterone in inducing attenuation, whereas 5β-DHT and 1-DeHT are ineffective.The nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling not only exerts genotropic actions in context with LPS signaling but also has a specific impact on cell function. This manifests itself as a testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-stimulated NO production of RAW 264.7 macrophages. In accordance, a recent report (55Friedl R. Brunner M. Moeslinger T. Spieckermann P.G. Life Sci. 2000; 68: 417-429Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar) also has shown testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-stimulated NO production. Our data demonstrate that nongenomic testosterone Ca2+signaling is the reason for testosterone-attenuated LPS-activated NO production, because the latter can be abolished by BAPTA.The testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-induced c-fos promoter activation and NO production may be thought to reflect only a simple uniform dampening of all LPS signaling parameters in macrophages through the increased free Ca2+ions. However, this attenuation is specific, which has to be deduced from our results. Thus, LPS activates all three MAPK families, ERK1/2, JNK/SAPK, and p38, in accordance with previous reports (39Hambleton J. Weinstein S.L. Lem L. DeFranco A.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 2774-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar, 41Feng G.J. Goodridge H.S. Harnett M.M. Wei X.Q. Nikolaev A.V. Higson A.P. Liew F.Y. J. Immunol. 1999; 163: 6403-6412PubMed Google Scholar). Testosterone, however, selectively down-regulates only the LPS-induced activation of p38, not that of ERK1/2 and JNK/SAPK. This p38 down-regulation is indeed due to nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling. When the free Ca2+ ions induced by testosterone are captured by BAPTA, p38 is again fully able to be stimulated by LPS. The central role of p38 MAPK is further substantiated by our finding that the p38 inhibitor, SB 203580, diminishes the LPS-induced activation of c-fos promoter activation and NO production and abolishes the responsiveness to testosterone of the remaining LPS effect. Collectively, our results indicate that there is a cross-talk of the testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling with the LPS signaling pathway. The testosterone-induced rise in [Ca2+]i attenuates the LPS-induced activation of p38, which further downstream attenuates both the LPS-activated c-fos promoter and NO production.The nongenomic iAR-independent testosterone signaling we have observed here in RAW 264.7 macrophages is a novel paradigm for a nongenomic steroid effect with impact on gene expression and cell functioning, independent of the cognate intracellular steroid receptor. This nongenomic signaling is presumably of importance with respect to the long known immunosuppressive activities of testosterone that are not yet explainable by the classic iAR response. In particular, the testosterone-induced nongenomic decrease in NO production of macrophages is compatible with our previous findings that testosterone dramatically diminishes the ability of mice to eliminate blood stages of Plasmodium chabaudi malaria (56Wunderlich F. Mossmann H. Helwig M. Schillinger G. Infect. Immun. 1988; 56: 2400-2406Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 57Wunderlich F. Marinovski P. Benten W.P.M. Schmitt-Wrede H.-P. Mossmann H. Parasite Immunol. (Oxf.). 1991; 13: 357-367Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Furthermore, testosterone not only prevents the development of protective immunity against P. chabaudi infections but even impairs the efficacy of protective vaccination against P. chabaudi malaria (58Wunderlich F. Maurin W. Benten W.P.M. Schmitt-Wrede H.-P. Vaccine. 1993; 11: 1097-1099Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). These immunosuppressive effects of testosterone are mediated neither through iAR nor, after aromatization of testosterone to E2, through iER (59Benten W.P.M. Wunderlich F. Mossmann H. J. In murine T-cells, for example, mAR mediate ligand-induced Ca2+ influx through non-voltage-gated, Ni2+-blockable Ca2+ channels (26Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Sekeris C.E. Wunderlich F. FEBS Lett. 1997; 407: 211-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar, 27Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Giese G. Wrehlke C. Stamm O. Sekeris C.E. Mossmann H. Wunderlich F. FASEB J. 1999; 13: 123-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar). In rat osteoblasts, testosterone induces both the influx of extracellular Ca2+ via voltage-gated Ca2+channels and Ca2+ release from intracellular stores through G-protein-coupled receptors activating phospholipase C via a pertussis toxin-sensitive G-protein (28Lieberherr M. Grosse B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7217-7223Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Murine macrophages of the cell line IC-21 respond to testosterone with predominantly intracellular Ca2+ mobilization mediated through G-protein-coupled receptors for testosterone (29Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Stamm O. Wrehlke C. Guo Z. Wunderlich F. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 3113-3123Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar, 30Wunderlich F. Benten W.P.M. Lieberherr M. Guo Z. Stamm O. Wrehlke C. Sekeris C.E. Mossmann H. Steroids. 2002; 67: 535-538Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). However, the functional importance of testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling, in particular with regard to gene expression and cell function, is not yet understood. To get information for possible genotropic effects of nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling, we have chosen as a model system mouse RAW 264.7 macrophages transiently or stably transfected with a c-fos promoter linked to human secreted alkaline phosphatase (SEAP) as a reporter, because the immediate early gene c-fos is known to be Ca2+-sensitive (31Roche E. Prentki M. Cell Calcium. 1994; 16: 331-338Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar, 32van Haasteren G., Li, S. Muda M. Susini S. Schlegel W. J. Recept. Signal Transduct. Res. 1999; 19: 481-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Here, we have demonstrated that testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling through mAR cannot directly activate the c-fos promoter. However, nongenomic testosterone signaling is able to exert genotropic actions in context with the LPS signaling pathway through p38 MAPK with impact on cell function. DISCUSSIONNongenomic actions of steroids on cells are obviously much more complex than anticipated to date. During recent years, a number of reports have appeared describing nongenomic steroid effects that are mediated through the classic intracellular steroid receptors. For instance, iER-mediated nongenomic E2 effects can activate members of the MAPK family such as ERK1/2 (5Migliaccio A., Di Domenico M. Castoria G. de Falco A. Bontempo P. Nola E. Auricchio F. Cell. 2001; 104: 719-730Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) because the Ca2+ response was not sensitive to the iER blockers, raloxifene, tamoxifen, and ICI 182,780. Rather, our data demonstrate that testosterone exerts its nongenomic iAR- and iER-independent effects through mAR. An increase in [Ca2+]i is also inducible with the plasma membrane-impermeable testosterone-BSA, and specific binding sites for testosterone can be localized on the surface of intact RAW-fos13 cells with testosterone-BSA conjugated to FITC. Though still unknown in molecular terms, the mAR mediate actions specific for different androgens; only testosterone and 5α-DHT induce about the same rise in [Ca2+]i, whereas 5β-DHT and 1-DeHT are ineffective in evoking changes in [Ca2+]i of RAW-fos13 macrophages.The nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling through mAR is not able in itself to induce genotropic actions in terms of activation of the stably and transiently transfected promoter of the Ca2+-inducible gene c-fos in RAW 264.7 cells. Nevertheless, the nongenomic testosterone signaling has the potency to induce genotropic actions. This becomes evident in the context of co-stimulation of the LPS signaling pathway. Thus, LPS stimulates c-fos promoter activation, and this stimulation is attenuated by testosterone-induced Ca2+ signaling. This attenuation can be completely abolished by BAPTA, and it is specific as supported by the following results. First, E2 causes the opposite effect of testosterone, namely an enhanced activation of thec-fos promoter following LPS stimulation. Second, testosterone has no effect on SV40 promoter activity. Third, 5α-DHT is just as effective as testosterone in inducing attenuation, whereas 5β-DHT and 1-DeHT are ineffective.The nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling not only exerts genotropic actions in context with LPS signaling but also has a specific impact on cell function. This manifests itself as a testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-stimulated NO production of RAW 264.7 macrophages. In accordance, a recent report (55Friedl R. Brunner M. Moeslinger T. Spieckermann P.G. Life Sci. 2000; 68: 417-429Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar) also has shown testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-stimulated NO production. Our data demonstrate that nongenomic testosterone Ca2+signaling is the reason for testosterone-attenuated LPS-activated NO production, because the latter can be abolished by BAPTA.The testosterone-induced attenuation of LPS-induced c-fos promoter activation and NO production may be thought to reflect only a simple uniform dampening of all LPS signaling parameters in macrophages through the increased free Ca2+ions. However, this attenuation is specific, which has to be deduced from our results. Thus, LPS activates all three MAPK families, ERK1/2, JNK/SAPK, and p38, in accordance with previous reports (39Hambleton J. Weinstein S.L. Lem L. DeFranco A.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 2774-2778Crossref PubMed Scopus (412) Google Scholar, 41Feng G.J. Goodridge H.S. Harnett M.M. Wei X.Q. Nikolaev A.V. Higson A.P. Liew F.Y. J. Immunol. 1999; 163: 6403-6412PubMed Google Scholar). Testosterone, however, selectively down-regulates only the LPS-induced activation of p38, not that of ERK1/2 and JNK/SAPK. This p38 down-regulation is indeed due to nongenomic testosterone Ca2+ signaling. When the free Ca2+ ions induced by testosterone are captured by BAPTA, p38 is again fully able to be stimulated by LPS. The central role of p38 MAPK is further substantiated by our finding that the p38 inhibitor, SB 203580, diminishes the LPS-induced activation of c-fos promoter activation and NO production and abolishes the responsiveness to testosterone of the remaining LPS effect. Collectively, our results indicate that there is a cross-talk of the testosterone-induced nongenomic Ca2+ signaling with the LPS signaling pathway. The testosterone-induced rise in [Ca2+]i attenuates the LPS-induced activation of p38, which further downstream attenuates both the LPS-activated c-fos promoter and NO production.The nongenomic iAR-independent testosterone signaling we have observed here in RAW 264.7 macrophages is a novel paradigm for a nongenomic steroid effect with impact on gene expression and cell functioning, independent of the cognate intracellular steroid receptor. This nongenomic signaling is presumably of importance with respect to the long known immunosuppressive activities of testosterone that are not yet explainable by the classic iAR response. In particular, the testosterone-induced nongenomic decrease in NO production of macrophages is compatible with our previous findings that testosterone dramatically diminishes the ability of mice to eliminate blood stages of Plasmodium chabaudi malaria (56Wunderlich F. (Oxf.). 1991; 13: 357-367Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). In contrast to previous assumptions, the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster possesses hemoglobin. This respiratory protein forms a monomer of about 17 kDa that is not exported into the hemolymph. Recombinant Drosophilahemoglobin displays a typical hexacoordinated deoxy spectrum and binds oxygen with an affinity of 0.12 torr. Four different hemoglobin transcripts have been identified, which are generated by two distinct promoters of the hemoglobin (glob1) gene but are identical in their coding regions. Putative binding sites for hypoxia-regulated transcription factors have been identified in the gene. Hemoglobin synthesis in Drosophila is mainly associated with the tracheal system and the fat body. This suggests that oxygen supply in insects may be more complex than thought previously and may depend on hemoglobin-mediated oxygen transport and storage in addition to simple diffusion.
