Mitsutomi M. Kono M. Matsumiya M. Chitin and Chitinases. Birkhauser Verlag, Basel/Switzerland1999: 111-123Crossref Scopus (51) Google Scholar). The role of these enzymes differs among the organisms. In insects, they degrade the biopolymer chitin, which is found in the exoskeleton and gut lining. Insect chitinases are induced by ecdysteroids at the time of molting and metamorphosis of the larvae to degrade most of the older chitin (2Kimura S. J. Insect Physiol. 1973; 19: 115-123Crossref Scopus (56) Google Scholar,3Koga D. Funakoshi T. Mizuki K. Utsumi T. Ide A. Insect Biochem. 1989; 19: 123-128Crossref Scopus (30) Google Scholar). Chitinase expression in the insects' exoskeletons and the guts normally occurs only during molting, where the chitin of the integument and the peritrophic membrane is presumably degraded (4Kramer K.J. Muthukrishnan S. Johnson L. White F. Carozzi N. Koziel M. Advances in Insect Control: The Role of Transgenic Plants. Taylor and Francis Publishers, Washington, D. C.1996: 185-193Google Scholar). Expression of the chitinase at a precise timing in insects demonstrates its fundamental role in the process of ecdysis. To elucidate the functions of the chitinases, the genes for these enzymes have also been isolated and characterized from many organisms, including mammals, insects, fungi, nematodes, and bacteria (5Overdijk B. Van Steijn G.J. Glycobiology. 1994; 4: 797-803Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 6Kramer K.J. Corpuz L.M. Choi H. Muthukrishnan S. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1993; 23: 691-701Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar, 7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 10Bogo M.R. Rota C.A. Pinto Jr., H. Ocampos M. Correa C.T. Varinstein M.H. Schrank A. Curr. Microbiol. 1998; 37: 221-225Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 11Fuhrman J.A. Parasitol. Today. 1995; 11: 259-261Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 12Watanabe T. Kobori K. Kiyotaka M. Fuji T. Sakai H. Uchida M. Tanaka H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 18567-18572Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). One of the structural features observed in chitinases is a multidomain architecture that includes catalytic domains, a cysteine rich chitin-binding domain, and a serine/threonine-rich domain that is glycosylated (13Tellam R.L. Parasitol. Today. 1996; 12: 291-292Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). The conserved motifs in most of the insects' chitinase genes reside in the central domains, which include the two regions implicated in catalysis (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). Differences occur in the cysteine-rich carboxyl domain and the proline/glutamate/serine/threonine-rich domain that is presumed to increase the susceptibility to proteolysis by a calcium-dependent protease (14Rogers S.G. Horsch R.B. Fraley R.T. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 118: 627-640Crossref Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 15Kramer K.J. Muthukrishnan S. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 887-900Crossref PubMed Scopus (315) Google Scholar). The silkworm, Bombyx mori, chitinases are well studied in our laboratory at both the enzymological and DNA levels (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 16Koga D. Sasaki Y. Uchiumi Y. Hirai N. Arakane Y. Nagamatsu Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 757-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 17Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Kameyama Y. Yoshioka T. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1999; 29: 537-547Crossref Scopus (31) Google Scholar).We have previously reported a complete exploration of the gene for the chitinase from B. mori (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). The gene's structural organization and functional motifs are consistent with the multidomain architecture of the proteins (13Tellam R.L. Parasitol. Today. 1996; 12: 291-292Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). The organizations of its functional domains are identical to the related gene from Manduca sexta(18Choi H.K. Choi K.H. Kramer K.J. Muthukrishnan S. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 37-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Hence, the genes for cuticular chitinases may be conserved among insect species (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). The coding regions of the genomic clone for the gene of B. mori chitinase have unique features both at exon 1/intron 1 splicing junctions and the 3′-end of the gene's coding regions (Fig. 1). First, the invariant nucleotides, GT, at the 5′ boundary of intron 1 are repeated in near proximity, so we suggested a differential splicing of the pre-mRNA (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). Another feature of this gene includes the incorporation of an additional sequence of 9 bp at the 3′-end of the coding regions (Fig.1). This sequence is absent from a chitinase cDNA clone studied earlier (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The open reading frame (ORF)1 is interrupted by the inclusion of the 9 bp due to the stop codon within these nucleotides. Therefore, the protein encoded by our chitinase gene is 22 amino acids smaller in size. Furthermore, another cDNA encoding a putative chitinase of B. mori has been reported recently (8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). There are some discrepancies between these two sequences of the chitinase cDNAs (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). They differ in the first amino acid of the mature N-terminal region and in the C-terminal coding region. In addition, there are direct repeats of 112 bp in the former cDNA sequence (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar), but these were not found in the latter study (8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Our previous studies on B. mori chitinases revealed that the first amino acid of the mature N-terminal sequences is alanine (16Koga D. Sasaki Y. Uchiumi Y. Hirai N. Arakane Y. Nagamatsu Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 757-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). These results are supported by deduced amino acid sequences of the chitinase cDNA that was studied by Mikitani et al. (8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Our study of the genomic clone for the gene of chitinase suggested the possible occurrence of all cDNAs sequences in a condition where an alternative splicing of the primary transcript of the chitinase occurs in the cell's nucleus.Alternative pre-mRNA splicing is an important mechanism in gene regulation and can include the use of alternative 5′- and/or 3′-splice sites, exon skipping, mutual exon exclusion, and/or intron retention (19Jiang H. Wang Y. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 55-58Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Dirksen W.P. Hampson R.K. Sun Q. Rottman F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6431-6436Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Jiang H. Wang Y. Huang Y. Mulnix A.B. Kandel J. Cole K. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28017-28023Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). Although intron retention is common in viral pre-mRNAs, it appears to be a relatively rare form of alternative splicing in vertebrates (22Sterner D.A. Berget S.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 2677-2687Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). It is believed that intron-containing mRNAs normally are prevented from being transported to the cytoplasm due to the formation of the spliceosome complex, which commits the pre-mRNA to the splicing pathway (23Green M.R. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1991; 7: 559-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (553) Google Scholar, 24Chang D.D. Sharp P.A. Cell. 1989; 59: 789-795Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (391) Google Scholar, 25Hamm J. Mattaj I.W. Cell. 1990; 63: 109-118Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar, 26Legrain P. Rosbash M. Cell. 1989; 57: 573-583Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar). However, there are examples of alternative intron retention in vertebrates that result in novel proteins due to translation of the intron sequences (27Cooke N.E. Ray J. Emery J.G. Liebhaber S.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 9001-9006Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 28Crabtree G.R. Kant J.A. Cell. 1982; 31: 159-166Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 29Hampson R.K. Rottman F.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 2673-2677Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 30Weil D. Brosset S. Dautry F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 5865-5876Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, there must be a mechanism by which a fraction of the mRNA molecules, containing an intact intron, escape the splicing pathway (20Dirksen W.P. Hampson R.K. Sun Q. Rottman F.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6431-6436Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because both the 5′- and 3′-splice sites are required for commitment of spliceosome complex formation (31Michaud S. Reed R. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 1008-1020Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar), it is possible that some suboptimal splice sites may prevent complex formation, thereby allowing an intron to be retained and intron-containing mRNAs to be transported to the cytoplasm.To obtain more insight into the splicing mechanism of chitinase primary transcript and to clarify the discrepancies observed on the N- and C-terminal amino acids, we have cloned B. morichitinase cDNAs from different stages of the fifth instar larvae and investigated the role of alternative pre-mRNA splicing in generating heterogeneous chitinase cDNAs within the silkworm. The results of this study are here described and discussed.DISCUSSIONSequence alignment of the coding regions in the B. morigenomic clone for the gene of chitinase (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) with the chitinase cDNA (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) revealed the correspondence of the two clones. However, the genomic clone incorporated an insert of 9 bp (5′-GTTCGTAAG-3′) at the C-terminal end of the gene, which was not reported in the chitinase cDNA (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The fifth nucleotide of the 9 bp was found to be A instead of G in some of the cDNA clones, which may be due to sequencing ambiguities. It appears that these nucleotides increase the size of the encoded protein by three amino acids. In contrast, the protein encoded by this clone was found to be of smaller size when compared with the one deduced from the chitinase cDNA (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) because of the presence of a stop codon within the 9-bp insert DNA (Fig.1).Previous results of the amino acid sequence analysis of the silkworm chitinases (16Koga D. Sasaki Y. Uchiumi Y. Hirai N. Arakane Y. Nagamatsu Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 757-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) revealed that the first residue of the N-terminal sequence is the nonpolar aliphatic amino acid, alanine. However, the reported cDNA clone (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) showed the first residue of the mature N-terminal sequence is the negatively charged amino acid, aspartate. Our results from the genomic clone of the B. mori chitinase gene suggested both cases to be true. To clarify the ambiguous results observed at the N-terminal region of the chitinase gene, to verify the existence of the 9-bp insert DNA in the mRNA, and to determine at which level these sequence differences are regulated, cDNA clones from the same insect species were synthesized at different stages of the fifth instar larvae and analyzed. Previously, we proposed that these discrepancies might be due to the insects' strains used in the different studies or otherwise regulated at the level of pre-mRNA splicing (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar).There are many genes reported to exhibit alternative RNA splicing in various organisms (34Breitbart R.E. Andreadis A. Nadal-Ginard B. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 56: 467-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar). Among insects, the tobacco hornworm, M. sexta, serpin gene produces 12 different serine proteinase inhibitors (serpins) through alternative pre-mRNA splicing (19Jiang H. Wang Y. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 55-58Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,21Jiang H. Wang Y. Huang Y. Mulnix A.B. Kandel J. Cole K. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28017-28023Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). This splicing process generates inhibitor diversity and potentially regulates a variety of proteinases, using the same protein framework joined to different reactive site region cassettes (19Jiang H. Wang Y. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 55-58Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). There are also about ten genes in Drosophila melanogasterfound to exhibit different patterns of alternative splicing. The class I glutathione S-transferase (GST) gene family was also found to undergo alternative splicing in Anopheles gambiae (35Ranson H. Collins F. Hemingway J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 14284-14289Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar) and Anopheles dirus (36Pongjaroenkit S. Jirajaroenrat K. Boonchauy C. Chanama U. Leetachewa S. Prapanthadara L. Ketterman A.J. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 75-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). In both species the GST gene contains six exons for four mature GST transcripts, which share exons 1 and 2 but vary between four different exon 3 sequences (exons 3A–3D) (36Pongjaroenkit S. Jirajaroenrat K. Boonchauy C. Chanama U. Leetachewa S. Prapanthadara L. Ketterman A.J. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 75-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). The sericin 1 primary transcript of B. mori is differentially spliced via a tissue- and developmentally regulated process (37Garel A. Deleage G. Prudhomme J.C. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 469-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). The structure of the sericin 1 gene is characterized by the presence of a large central alternative exon, which encodes an internally repetitive sequence (37Garel A. Deleage G. Prudhomme J.C. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 469-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). The serpin gene-1 from M. sexta is characterized by the presence of 12 alternate forms of exon 9. The splicing pathway apparently allows inclusion of only one exon 9 per molecule of a mature serpin-1 mRNA (21Jiang H. Wang Y. Huang Y. Mulnix A.B. Kandel J. Cole K. Kanost M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 28017-28023Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar).In this study we demonstrated that the B. mori chitinase gene exhibits four patterns of alternative pre-mRNA splicing: one at the 5′ region and three at the 3′ region (Figs. 5 and 6). In some of the cDNA clones amplified (SP-1/(1–10)2, SP-2/ (1–10)1, SP-2/(1–10)2, and SP-2/(1–14)), the 3′ border of exon 1 was found to be three nucleotides downstream (GTG/gtgagt), giving a more conventional intron entry site, gtgagt (37Garel A. Deleage G. Prudhomme J.C. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 469-477Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar) (Tables I and II and Fig. 1). In this case the gene undergoes differential splicing through two alternative 5′-intron splicing consensus sites at the boundary between exon 1 and intron 1 (FIG. 4, FIG. 5, FIG. 6). Although the selection of the correct pairs of 5′- and 3′-intron splicing sites in pre-mRNA splicing process is the central problem, evidence is accumulating in support of the notion that combinations between certain intron entry sites are preferred to others (34Breitbart R.E. Andreadis A. Nadal-Ginard B. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 56: 467-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar). Based on this result, we were able to interpret that the discrepancies observed in the mature N-terminal sequences among the N-terminal amino acid sequence ofB. mori chitinases (16Koga D. Sasaki Y. Uchiumi Y. Hirai N. Arakane Y. Nagamatsu Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 757-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar), chitinase cDNAs (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), and the genomic clone for the gene of chitinase (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) were due to this alternative splicing process. The products of the splicing are two mature transcripts encoding two mature proteins: one starts with alanine and the other with aspartate. The splicing product that yields alanine as the first residue of the mature N-terminal increases the coding region of the chitinase gene by one amino acid, whereas the one that produces aspartate as the first residue of the mature N-terminal is one residue shorter. Exclusion or inclusion of the alternatively spliced triplet does not interrupt the ORF of the corresponding mature transcripts. It is noteworthy that the 5′ region in the B. mori chitinase gene (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) is very unique compared with its closely related gene from M. sexta (18Choi H.K. Choi K.H. Kramer K.J. Muthukrishnan S. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 37-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar), both in sequence and structural motifs, because there is only one functional 5′-intron splicing consensus sequences in the junction between exon 1 and intron 1 in the M. sexta gene for chitinase (Table I). This might be attributed to species differences.Another striking feature of the B. mori chitinase gene is its incorporation of 9 bp at the 3′ region (9Abdel-Banat B.M.A. Koga D. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 2001; 31: 497-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). This insertion mediates direct repeats of 112 bp. However, if the 9-bp insert DNA is summed up to the upstream 112 bp, the direct repeats will be 121 bp (Fig. 5). There are two types of splicing patterns in this region of the gene. A splicing occurs via exclusion of the upstream 121-bp direct repeat in some of the mature transcripts (SP-1/(1–10)2, SP-2/(1–10)2, and SP-2/(1–14)) (Table II), because the 3′-end of the 9-bp insert DNA serves as an alternative intron splicing site. The stop codon in the product of this splicing pattern was shifted to the downstream 121-bp direct repeat. The proteins encoded by either inclusion or exclusion of the upstream direct repeat will be of similar size in terms of their amino acids (Fig. 6).To verify that the cDNAs described were produced by splicing and were not transcribed from additional gene sequences elsewhere in the genome, the same primer set was used in PCR with genomic DNA as the template to amplify the 3′ region around the direct repeats. Nucleic acids that differ by 121 bp are detectable on agarose gel. The DNA fragments amplified from SP-0 through SP-3 genomic DNAs were typically the same size as expected (Fig. 7A). The same primer set was used in PCR with cDNA clones that exhibited differential splicing of the upstream 121-bp direct repeat as the templates (Fig.7B). The results clearly indicated that the variant mature transcripts investigated are the products of a single gene, which in turn supports the concept that the copy number of B. morichitinase gene is 1 per haploid genome (8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). In addition, these results are inconsistent with the possibility that the nucleotides of the 9 bp are part of a large intron separating the repeated sequences. Moreover, the 9-bp insert DNA was also determined by sequencing to be alternatively spliced (Figs. 4 and 5). The mechanism by which the gene undergoes splicing of the 9 bp is not clear. However, the 9 bp may be spliced in a combinatorial fashion, because, in this pattern of splicing, the alternatively spliced genes contain entire exons that are individually included or excluded from the mature mRNA (34Breitbart R.E. Andreadis A. Nadal-Ginard B. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 56: 467-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar). The combinatorial exons, each 12–18 bp long, are among the smallest reported (34Breitbart R.E. Andreadis A. Nadal-Ginard B. Ann. Rev. Biochem. 1987; 56: 467-495Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar). However, the cardiac troponin T (TnT) gene has an exon of only six nucleotides in length (38Cooper T.A. Ordahl C.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 11140-11148Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A previously reported B. mori chitinase cDNA (7Kim M.G. Shin S.W. Bae K.-S. Kim S.C. Park H.-Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1998; 28: 163-171Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) incorporates the 112-bp direct repeats but is devoid of the 9 bp, whereas the other reported cDNA from the same insect (8Mikitani K. Sugasaki T. Shimada T. Kobayashi M. Gustafsson J.-A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37725-37732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) lacks the upstream 121-bp direct repeat. All of these results together support the possibility of splicing of the 9 bp separately and irrespective of the other sequences of the primary transcript. Furthermore, exclusion of this insertion from the primary transcript yields a mature mRNA that encodes a protein 22 amino acids longer than that from a mature transcript including the insertion due to generation of a premature stop codon (Figs. 3 and 6). Exclusion of the triplet (GTG) at the exon 1 and intron 1 boundary and retention of the 9 bp at the 3′ region appeared more commonly in the mature transcripts from the late stages of the fifth instar larvae. However, generally, the alternative splicing phenomenon in the B. mori chitinase gene is not dependent on the fifth instar developmental stage (Table II).To assess the changes in the levels of chitinase mRNAs in the fifth instar larvae epidermal tissues, total RNAs from the respective tissues were analyzed by Northern blotting. Chitinase mRNA was undetected by Northern blotting on the day when the fifth instar larvae started spinning behavior. However, it was present at a very low level 1 day later, and its level increased sharply on the second day and gradually onward (Fig. 8A). The mature mRNAs expressing chitinase were also detected by RT-PCR (Fig. 8B). These data demonstrated the chitinase mRNA was transcribed even at the SP-0 stage, and it was detectable by RT-PCR when using only half of the amount of total RNA that was used in Northern blotting. This result strongly supports the concept of a gradual expression of the chitinase mRNA in B. mori from the day when the fifth instar larvae initiated spinning behavior and also supports the development-specific expression of chitinase, which was also detected in M. sexta larvae (6Kramer K.J. Corpuz L.M. Choi H. Muthukrishnan S. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1993; 23: 691-701Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar).Two mechanisms were proposed for the generation of multiple functional chitinases from a single gene in B. mori. The chitinases may be processed from a larger one by limited proteolysis from the C-terminal side (16Koga D. Sasaki Y. Uchiumi Y. Hirai N. Arakane Y. Nagamatsu Y. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 27: 757-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Another mechanism is the regulation of the enzymes expression at the gene level through alternative splicing of pre-mRNA. We present here the data that prove the alternative splicing mechanism. The role of this splicing mechanism in generating multiple functional chitinases in the silkworm was further demonstrated by expressing the alternatively spliced cDNA clones in E. coli.
